channel.title: Latest alerts from washingtonpost.com
channel.description: An unofficial feed created by Derek Willis.

item.title: How different are urban and rural Americans? Take our quiz to find out.
item.description: How different are urban and rural Americans? Take our quiz to find out.

item.title: FDA will remove warning on hormone therapy for menopause, potentially widening access
item.description: Since 2003, the drugs have included a black-box warning that they may increase the risk of heart attacks, strokes, blood clots and certain cancers. Some doctors say the labels have long prevented women from taking medications aimed at treating the symptoms of menopause.

item.title: Carolyn Hax: How to brush off Mom’s critiques behind her fake praise?
item.description: Carolyn Hax: How to brush off Mom’s critiques behind her fake praise?

item.title: The Post’s new food critic is Elazar Sontag — and he won’t be anonymous
item.description: For the past three and a half years, Sontag was the restaurant editor at Bon Appétit magazine, where he searched for the best new dining spots in the United States. He won’t try to keep his face off the internet, but he will cover D.C.-area restaurants with the rigor and attention that locals deserve.

item.title: Supreme Court won’t hear challenge to its landmark same-sex marriage ruling
item.description: The announcement indicates there is not an appetite among the high court’s conservative majority to revisit the case known as Obergefell v. Hedges, one of the court’s most significant decisions in recent years.

item.title: What’s the best place to raise kids? See how your county ranks.
item.description: Find where to move based on your priorities.

item.title: The Justice Department is struggling as thousands of experienced attorneys exit and few are replaced
item.description: The Trump administration has backfilled only a fraction of open jobs, with the process snarled by a lack of qualified candidates, bureaucratic delays and hiring freezes, according to people familiar with Justice Department hirings.

item.title: Shutdown vote. BBC resignations. DOJ vacancies. Anti-vaccine event. Hiring slowdown. Sports betting. Walking study. Catch up now.
item.description: Catch up in minutes with these 7 stories.

item.title: Senate takes key vote toward ending government shutdown after group of Democrats strikes deal with Republicans
item.description: Seven Democratic senators and one independent joined with almost all of the chamber’s Republicans to take the first step toward reopening the government. Sunday’s vote is the first of many that will be necessary to pass the agreement in the upper chamber.

item.title: How to declutter with the 90/90 rule and 8 other numerical guides
item.description: Like recipes, organizing systems often rely on numbers to make decluttering more straightforward. “Saying ‘If you have not used it in 90 days and you will not in the next 90, let it go’ makes it clear,” one home refresh expert says. Try this menu of numerically oriented methods to help you start your cleaning journey.

item.title: Former NFL commissioner Paul Tagliabue dies at 84. He led the league from 1989 to 2006.
item.description: The apparent cause of death was heart failure complicated by Parkinson’s disease, according to Tagliabue’s family, who said he died at his home in Chevy Chase, Maryland. He succeeded Pete Rozelle as commissioner and was succeeded by Roger Goodell.

item.title: Still need to finish this weekend’s On the Record? We’ve got you.
item.description: Play now to finish out your score for the week.

item.title: Trump administration orders states to pause efforts to pay full November SNAP benefits
item.description: The White House is instead asking states to issue partial payments, which are about 65 percent of a usual Supplemental Nutrition Assistance Program benefit. An Agriculture Department memo warns states that if they fail to comply, they will face consequences.

item.title: How a childhood virus can contribute to dementia later, and what you can do about it
item.description: A new study suggests that the shingles vaccine may help prevent dementia by reducing the risk of varicella-zoster virus reactivation.

item.title: Crossword and a coffee: Solve the Sunday puzzle now
item.description: Crossword and a coffee: Solve the Sunday puzzle now

item.title: The secret history of how Thomas Jefferson’s words were doctored inside his memorial
item.description: This installment of The Post's seven-part series explores how Jefferson's great-great-grandson pushed to portray him as an abolitionist, leaving a misleading impression about his actions on equality and slavery.

item.title: Far-right provocateur Nick Fuentes is triggering a MAGA civil war
item.description: Once barred from nearly every social media platform, Fuentes’s resurgence is driving a wedge through President Donald Trump’s MAGA movement.

item.title: As Congress spars over shutdown, ACA premium costs are rising. These 8 Americans showed us how much.
item.description: Premium costs for health insurance sold through the Affordable Care Act are soaring because of the expiration of enhanced subsidies at the heart of the government shutdown.

item.title: How many guesses will Keyword take you today? Try to beat the average now.
item.description: How many guesses will Keyword take you today? Try to beat the average now.

item.title: ‘Take On Me,’ the ultimate synth-pop hit song, has been stuck in our heads since the 1980s. Here’s how it got there.
item.description: The full story of how A-ha emerged from the Norwegian tundra with the ultimate pop song — and its unexpected afterlife.

item.title: Supreme Court temporarily blocks order on releasing SNAP benefits
item.description: The order pauses, for now, a lower court ruling that would have required the Trump administration to release November benefits in full.

item.title: Federal judge blocks Trump from deploying National Guard in Oregon
item.description: District Judge Karin J. Immergut, who was appointed by President Donald Trump, said the attempted deployment in Portland exceeded his authority.

item.title: The states where more people are likely to die before turning 65
item.description: A new study reveals an increase in premature deaths among 18- to 64-year-olds, with Black adults and certain states disproportionately affected.

item.title: Trump administration asks Supreme Court to block order on releasing SNAP benefits
item.description: A federal judge had directed the administration to release full benefits for November. The administration said Friday it was working to release those benefits.

item.title: Nobel-winning scientist James Watson dies at 97. He helped reveal the structure of DNA, illuminating the genetic blueprint for life.
item.description: The discovery of DNA’s double helix structure — made with his research partner, Francis Crick, and collaborators Maurice Wilkins and Rosalind Franklin — forever altered the study of biology and influenced modern life in ways that extended far beyond the academic. His reputation was later tarnished when some of his writings were condemned as racist and sexist.

item.title: U.S. steps up presence in Gaza to support ceasefire, replacing Israel as administrator of humanitarian aid
item.description: The move relegates Israel to a secondary role in determining how and what humanitarian relief can enter Gaza as the U.S. takes the lead, according to several people familiar with the transition.

item.title: Cornell University agrees to pay $60 million in agreement with Trump administration that restores the university’s research funding
item.description: The deal closes federal investigations into Cornell, which is the fourth Ivy League university to reach an agreement with the administration.

item.title: Sabrina Carpenter, Lady Gaga, Bad Bunny lead nominations from the Recording Academy
item.description: New categories were added this year, including for traditional country album. Here’s the list of the top nominees.

item.title: 10 questions, and don't forget the bonus wager! Finish off your week with On the Record.
item.description: Think you’ve got what it takes to earn a perfect score? Take today’s longer news quiz and complete your point total for the week.

item.title: Second woman says U.S. Anglican Church archbishop sexually harassed her
item.description: A new allegation adds to a crisis facing the denomination founded by conservatives who split from the Episcopal Church in the early 2000s over an openly gay bishop.

item.title: Flight cuts. Voter shifts. Supreme Court. ‘Sandwich guy.’ Climate talks. Bari Weiss. Better aging. Catch up now.
item.description: Catch up in minutes with these 7 stories.

item.title: Heritage Foundation staff in open revolt over leader’s defense of Tucker Carlson
item.description: The recent departures and condemnations stemmed from increasing frustration with Kevin Roberts’s handling of Project 2025 and internal sexism allegations.

item.title: Elon Musk wins $1 trillion pay package, tying him to Tesla for a decade and setting him up to be world's first trillionaire
item.description: In an era of skyrocketing CEO pay, the award is unprecedented. The decision passed with more than 75 percent of the vote.

item.title: Federal judge orders Trump administration to release full SNAP benefits by Friday
item.description: In his ruling, Judge Jack McConnell said the USDA was causing “irreparable harm” by not releasing full funding. “The evidence shows that people will go hungry,” he added.

item.title: Congressional Budget Office believed to have been hacked by foreign actor, people familiar with the situation say
item.description: The nonpartisan office makes economic projections for lawmakers and evaluates legislation for how much it would add or subtract from the national debt. The breach potentially exposes key financial data.

item.title: Supreme Court allows Trump to end policy of self-identifying gender on passports
item.description: The justices overturned for now a lower-court decision that blocked an executive order by President Donald Trump that required passports to reflect a person’s sex as listed on their birth certificate. The decision is the latest in a string of orders by the high court rolling back gay and transgender rights.

item.title: Jury finds D.C. ‘sandwich guy’ not guilty of assaulting officer
item.description: Sean C. Dunn admitted he flung the hoagie at a federal agent. His attorneys called it a “harmless gesture” of protest as Trump commandeered D.C. police.

item.title: Virginia teacher shot by 6-year-old student wins $10 million in lawsuit against former assistant principal
item.description: Abby Zwerner was a teacher at Richneck Elementary School when she was shot by her first-grade student in 2023.

item.title: Trump announces deal to lower price of GLP-1 drugs that help with weight loss
item.description: The president announced concessions from Eli Lilly and Novo Nordisk that will lower the price of the companies’ weight-loss drugs for some patients who are covered by Medicare and Medicaid.

item.title: Carolyn Hax: Son’s friend goes by he/him, but his parents still use she/her
item.description: Carolyn Hax: Son’s friend goes by he/him, but his parents still use she/her

item.title: Preliminary list of airports affected by flight cuts amid shutdown includes those serving Atlanta, New York, L.A., D.C. and others
item.description:
A person briefed on the process who spoke on the condition of anonymity to discuss internal plans cautioned the list could change as discussions continue.
The flight reductions were announced Thursday as part of a Trump administration effort aimed at easing pressure on air traffic controllers and other aviation staff working without pay during the government shutdown.

item.title: The great GOP migration has begun, Republican Jeff Flake writes
item.description: The midterms promise a reality check — and growing defections from disastrous MAGA orthodoxy.

item.title: Cloning dogs in today’s On the Record
item.description: Answer now to earn your Thursday points.

item.title: Nancy Pelosi announces her retirement and will wrap up her historic, almost four-decade run in Congress at the end of her term
item.description: The San Francisco Democrat, who became the first woman speaker of the House, is known for bending the chamber to her will and keeping her often narrow majority in line through a combination of persuasion and fear of punishment.

item.title: Layoffs rise to recession-like levels through October, new report says
item.description: Employers have announced 1.1 million job cuts so far this year, the highest reading since the pandemic, according to a report from Challenger, Gray & Christmas, a private firm that tracks workplace reductions.

item.title: Election fallout. Tariff doubts. Flight cuts. ICE chase. Musk payout. Think tank revolt. AI therapy. Catch up now.
item.description: Catch up in minutes with these 7 stories.

item.title: At 89, she’s a top nutritionist. Here’s what she eats in a day to stay healthy — and some treats she can’t resist.
item.description: Marion Nestle’s blunt advice, sharp criticism of food companies and popular books have made her one of the most recognizable names in nutrition.

item.title: Trump administration orders 10 percent reduction in flights in 40 U.S. markets as shutdown drags on
item.description: The unprecedented move, effective Friday, comes just a few weeks before the busy Thanksgiving travel period.

item.title: Supreme Court appears skeptical of Trump’s authority to impose sweeping tariffs
item.description: In oral arguments, the justices sharply questioned attorneys in the most significant case over President Donald Trump’s policies to reach the high court to date — and the first in which the justices could be called on to render a final decision.

item.title: Mapping Democrats’ sweep of Virginia, New Jersey and New York
item.description: Democrats scored major gubernatorial wins in Virginia and New Jersey and captured the New York City mayoral race as voters chose candidates who focused on affordability and capitalized on frustration with President Donald Trump. The Washington Post visualized how East Coast elections played out.
